text:
be prepared to break down the "third wall" in your marketing.

our weekly newsletter—which we send to potential buyers of CXL Institute—features a few paragraphs of thoughts from Peep that often cover challenges or experiments about marketing...CXL Institute.

honestly, that's easier than trying to pretend that we're _not_ marketing to marketers, and i think people appreciate the transparency.

one of the big benefits: we are our own target audience, which makes us good beta testers of ideas and features, and makes it easier to write VOC-type copy in-house without having to do a ton of added research.

text:
I’ve been marketing to marketers since 2013 (first at Influitive and now at PathFactory) and it’s a fun job! While I agree that marketers can be tougher to please than some other personas, they also appreciate great marketing more than other personas. And, as a marketer, you have something to teach them yourself as you “drink your own champagne” so to speak. This is the key as <@UJDPMTREY> says above. Addressing your audience directly, like friends, and sharing your learnings is really the way to get their attention. That can be tough to do in other industries because as a marketer I would have to rely much more heavily on SMEs to communicate similar learnings.

In terms of empowerment to buy, some marketing personas definitely have more buying power and budget than others. Marketing to demand gen marketers at PathFactory is much easier than marketing to customer marketers at Influitive was, for example, because DG actually has budget and autonomous buying power.

text: If there’s one thing I see leaders get wrong at martech companies, it’s that they try to do these big sweeping visionary pieces telling marketers all the things they’re doing wrong and all the things they should be doing to win. And it just never works. Ever. Now that I’m more grizzled and confident, I can swat away most exec attempts at this kind of thing, but earlier in my career I wasn’t quite as confident. Marketers love to learn how to do their jobs better. They don’t love reading a novel about why everything they do sucks and how there’s a better way.

text: <@UJDPMTREY> touched on this above, but marketers love seeing behind the scenes. Open up the curtain and show them what you're doing to market to them, what's working and what isn't. I've felt Ahrefs starting to do this really well, too.
